Authors: Alistair Ross McTaggart, Mary Catherine Aime
Title:
The delimitation of Coleosporium asterum in the United
States
Keywords:
Pucciniomycotina, Pucciniales, Uredinales, morphology,
systematics, maximum likelihood, Large Subunit region
Abstract:
Coleosporium asterum, a rust fungus originally described
from Japan that alternates between hosts in the Pinaceae and Asteraceae,
is believed to form a species complex in North America. A systematic
analysis using three rDNA loci was conducted to determine the
relationships among species of Coleosporium, including C. asterum. Two
phylogenetically distant groups of C. asterum were recovered that
represent different species in the United States, neither of which
appear to be conspecific with the Asiatic species. Coleosporium
kanekoium is described to accommodate a monophyletic group on Solidago
(Asteraceae) within the southeastern United States. Coleosporium asterum
remains a species complex within the United States and Asia. This study
illustrates species delimitation in Coleosporium cannot be defined
solely by host, spore morphology or a single rDNA locus.
